metadata.titleEn: Global marine isoprene emission data set (2001-2020)
metadata.description: This dataset provides information on global hourly marine isoprene emission flux for the period 2001-2020. The dataset used MODIS marine chlorophyll concentration data, diffuse attenuation coefficients, VIIRS water-leaving radiation data and ERA5 reanalysis meteorological data as input. Hourly emission fluxes of isoprene from two marine sources were calculated, including marine biological emissions and photochemical emissions in the sea microsurface, using the latest physical, biological and chemical processes and empirical relationships derived from recent obervations and laboratory studies. Data for Netcdf format file, containing biological emissions' flux_bio and photochemical emissions' flux_sml 'two variables as well as latitude and longitude information, with temporal resolution for hours. The dataset provides two spatial and temporal resolutions, including daily 1 degree grid and hourly 0.25 degree grid . The reliability of this dataset is verified by comparing the results of marine isoprene concentrations and emission fluxes from this dataset with those from previous observations. Isoprene, as an important biological volatile organic compound (BVOC), is a major source of secondary organic aerosols (SOA) from natural sources in terrestrial and marine area. This dataset can be used as an input data for earth system model simulation in formation of marine SOA. This work in order to further study the effect of air-sea system for Marine SOA formation and its climate effect laid a solid foundation.
metadata.instructions: File name: Marine isoprene emission data stored in NetCDF format, each netcdf file contains biological emissions(flux_bio) and sea microlayer emission (flux_sml) and the corresponding longitude and latitude variables. File name is yyyy_mm. nc, including yyyy on behalf of the year, the mm on behalf of the corresponding month. Such as 2001_01.nc represents the January 2001 global marine isoprene hourly emission data. Also, the data with daily 1-degree grids is named yyyy_ Daily1deg.nc.

literatureList.titleEn: Enhanced dataset of global marine isoprene emissions from biogenic and photochemical processes for the period 2001–2020
literatureList.referenceEn: Cui, L., Xiao, Y., Hu, W., Song, L., Wang, Y., Zhang, C., Fu, P., and Zhu, J. (2023). Enhanced dataset of global marine isoprene emissions from biogenic and photochemical processes for the period 2001–2020, Earth System Science Data, 15, 5403–5425, https://doi.org/10.5194/essd-15-5403-2023.

fundVOList.titleEn: Study of the interaction processes and mechanisms between air-sea system and marine organic aerosols

background: Biogenic organic volatile compounds (BVOCs), one of the most important components in the marine boundary layer (MBL), play an important role in the formation of marine secondary organic aerosols (SOAs), particularly in pristine remote oceans. Among all the non-methane BVOC species, isoprene exhibits large emissions and demonstrates significant atmospheric chemical reactivity in the marine environment. Within the MBL, isoprene can undergo oxidation, leading to the formation of semi-volatile organic compounds (SVOCs) and low-volatility organic compounds (LVOCs) such as methacrolein and methacrylic acid. Due to its significant emissions and capacity to contribute to SOA formation, marine isoprene plays a crucial role in aerosol generation and growth within the MBL. Previous studies have estimated marine isoprene emissions using both bottom–up and top–down approaches. The estimation of BIO emissions is typically derived from an empirical linear relationship established between ocean chlorophyll concentration and isoprene emissions. The estimation of SML emissions is based on the surfactants present in the SML and their associated photochemical processes. Previous estimates also encountered challenges related to data availability and unclear emission mechanisms, leading to uncertainties in the estimated emissions. Estimations for high latitudes are particularly lacking due to limited satellite data coverage during the winter months. Moreover, previous estimations of vertical distributions of chlorophyll and isoprene concentrations did not entirely align with current observed vertical profiles in the subsurface ocean.
research objective: Here we built a module to present a 20-year (2001–2020) global hourly dataset for marine isoprene emissions, including phytoplankton-generated biological emissions (BIO emissions) and photochemistry-generated emissions in the sea surface microlayer (SML emissions) based on the latest advancements in biological, physical, and chemical processes, with high spatial resolutions. This work provides the foundation for further studies into the impact of the air–sea system on marine SOA formation and its climate effect. Our dataset can be used as input data for climate or atmospheric chemistry models. The module can also be coupled with the earth system model to calculate marine isoprene emissions online.
challenges: Previous estimates also encountered challenges related to data availability and unclear emission mechanisms, leading to uncertainties in the estimated emissions. Estimations for high latitudes are particularly lacking due to limited satellite data coverage during the winter months. Moreover, previous estimations of vertical distributions of chlorophyll and isoprene concentrations did not entirely align with current observed vertical profiles in the subsurface ocean. The relationships between emissions and marine and meteorological factors, established on the basis of localized phytoplankton populations, are regionally constrained and may not be applicable in all situations. These limitations led to discrepancies between observed emissions and the estimations obtained using previous methods.
methods: We obtained 20-year (2001–2020) monthly average chlorophyll concentration data at 9 km resolution and 490 nm downwelling radiative flux diffuse attenuation coefficient data with the same spatial resolution from the MODIS Level 3 product in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) Ocean Color Web (NASA, 2022a, b). These two datasets were averaged into grids with a resolution of 0.25°×0.25° to fit the fifth-generation European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) atmospheric reanalysis (ERA5) dataset used in this study. Additionally, the monthly normalized water-leaving radiance at 410 nm for the period 2012–2020 from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA CoastWatch, 2017) was utilized to determine the distribution of phytoplankton types together with chlorophyll concentration. The phytoplankton-generated emission module was developed based on the assumption that the concentration of isoprene in the ocean remains static in each hour. The isoprene production rate, P, was determined by a linear relationship between chlorophyll concentration, radiation, and the diffuse attenuation coefficient at 490 nm, as well as the classification of phytoplankton types. The aforementioned equations were utilized to estimate the hourly marine isoprene emissions originating from phytoplankton within each grid, with a spatial resolution of 0.25°×0.25°. The dominant phytoplankton type was determined using monthly satellite-observed normalized water-leaving radiance at 410 nm and seawater chlorophyll concentration. An interpolation for hourly isoprene BIO and SML emissions is applied during the boreal summer (June, July, and August) and winter months (December, November, and January) in this study.
dataset: Here we built a module to present a 20-year (2001–2020) global hourly dataset for marine isoprene emissions, including phytoplankton-generated biological emissions (BIO emissions) and photochemistry-generated emissions in the sea surface microlayer (SML emissions) based on the latest advancements in biological, physical, and chemical processes, with high spatial resolutions. Our dataset suggests the annual global marine isoprene emissions amount to 1.097 ±0.009 Tg yr−1. Among these, the BIO emissions are 0.481±0.008 Tg yr−1 while SML emissions contribute 0.616±0.003 Tg yr−1. Here, we generated a 0.25◦×0.25◦grid dataset of global marine isoprene emissions covering a 20-year period from 2001 to 2020 with an updated method combining the latest emission features and state-of-the-art influencing factors. Two distinct types of emissions, BIO emissions and SML emissions, were calculated by satellite-derived monthly ocean chlorophyll concentration data from the MODIS and ERA5 hourly meteorological reanalysis separately.
findings: Our dataset suggests the annual global marine isoprene emissions amount to 1.097 ±0.009 Tg yr−1. The annual total isoprene emissions across the tropical ocean show a declining trend from 2001 to 2020. Most ocean regions exhibit a 1-year emission period, whereas a significant intraseasonal period is found in the tropical ocean.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method for marine isoprene emissions rely on satellite-derived ocean chlorophyll concentration data?
Is there a challenge in estimating marine isoprene emissions due to limited satellite data coverage in high latitudes during winter months?
Can the 20-year global hourly dataset of marine isoprene emissions be used as input data for climate or atmospheric chemistry models?

Disjunctive.Question: Are marine isoprene emissions more effectively estimated using satellite-derived chlorophyll concentration data, atmospheric reanalysis data, or a combination of both?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods were used to estimate marine isoprene emissions from 2001 to 2020?
Concept Completion.Answer: MODIS Level 3 product, ERA5 atmospheric reanalysis dataset, NOAA

Concept Completion.Question: When were the challenges related to unclear emission mechanisms and limited satellite data particularly significant in estimating marine isoprene emissions?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to estimate marine isoprene emissions?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to estimate marine isoprene emissions involves obtaining monthly average chlorophyll concentration data and downwelling radiative flux diffuse attenuation coefficient data from the MODIS Level 3 product, which are averaged into grids to align with the ECMWF ERA5 dataset.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered in estimating marine isoprene emissions?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge encountered in estimating marine isoprene emissions is the limited satellite data coverage during winter months, especially at high latitudes, which leads to uncertainties in the estimated emissions.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that provides information on marine isoprene emissions over a lengthy period?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that provides information on marine isoprene emissions over a lengthy period is the 20-year global hourly dataset for marine isoprene emissions from 2001 to 2020, which includes both phytoplankton-generated biological emissions and photochemistry-generated emissions in the sea surface microlayer.

Feature Specification.Question: What specific features are considered when estimating the spatial and temporal variations of marine isoprene emissions?
Feature Specification.Answer: chlorophyll concentration, downwelling radiative flux diffuse attenuation coefficient, phytoplankton types, meteorological conditions

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges are associated with the data availability and emission mechanism clarity in estimating marine isoprene emissions?
Feature Specification.Answer: limited satellite data coverage in high latitudes during winter months, discrepancies in vertical profiles of chlorophyll and isoprene concentrations, uncertainties in estimating emissions, regionally constrained relationships between emissions and marine and meteorological factors

Quantification.Question: What is the total annual global marine isoprene emissions amount as suggested by a dataset over a 20-year period?
How many types of emissions are quantified in a dataset focusing on marine isoprene emissions?
What is the spatial resolution used in a dataset for estimating hourly marine isoprene emissions?

Definition.Question: What does 'phytoplankton-generated biological emissions (BIO emissions)' mean in the context of marine isoprene emissions?
Definition.Answer: Phytoplankton-generated biological emissions (BIO emissions) refer to the production of isoprene by phytoplankton within the marine environment. This process is driven by a linear relationship between chlorophyll concentration, radiation, and the diffuse attenuation coefficient at 490 nm, as well as the classification of phytoplankton types. It represents the biological component of marine isoprene emissions, distinct from photochemistry-generated emissions in the sea surface microlayer.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'photochemistry-generated emissions in the sea surface microlayer (SML emissions)' in marine isoprene studies?
Definition.Answer: Photochemistry-generated emissions in the sea surface microlayer (SML emissions) refer to the production of isoprene through photochemical processes occurring at the ocean's surface microlayer. These emissions are driven by surfactants present in the SML and their associated photochemical activities, providing a distinct source of isoprene emissions separate from those generated by phytoplankton.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods used for estimating phytoplankton-generated biological emissions (BIO emissions) compare to those used for photochemistry-generated emissions in the sea surface microlayer (SML emissions)?
Comparison.Answer: The estimation of BIO emissions is derived from a linear relationship between ocean chlorophyll concentration, radiation, and the diffuse attenuation coefficient, while SML emissions are estimated based on the surfactants present in the sea surface microlayer and their associated photochemical processes.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do challenges related to data availability and unclear emission mechanisms differ between BIO and SML emission estimations?
Comparison.Answer: Challenges for both BIO and SML emissions include data availability and unclear emission mechanisms, but the estimation of BIO emissions specifically struggles with aligning vertical distributions of chlorophyll and isoprene concentrations with observed profiles, while SML emissions face difficulties due to limited satellite data coverage, especially in high latitude regions during winter months.

Comparison.Question: How does the spatial resolution of datasets used in estimating marine isoprene emissions impact the accuracy of BIO and SML emissions estimation?
Comparison.Answer: The spatial resolution, such as the 0.25°×0.25° grid used for the dataset, allows for high-resolution estimation of both BIO and SML emissions, potentially enhancing accuracy by incorporating detailed spatial variability in chlorophyll concentration and meteorological factors. However, the regional constraints of phytoplankton populations and meteorological factors might still lead to discrepancies.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying patterns can be inferred from the 20-year trend of marine isoprene emissions, and how might these patterns impact the modeling of secondary organic aerosols in marine environments?
Interpretation.Answer: The 20-year trend of marine isoprene emissions shows a declining trend in annual total emissions across the tropical ocean from 2001 to 2020. This pattern might impact the modeling of secondary organic aerosols by suggesting a potential decrease in isoprene's contribution to aerosol formation over time, which could influence the understanding of aerosol generation and growth within the marine boundary layer.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of satellite-derived chlorophyll concentration data and meteorological reanalysis data inform the accuracy and reliability of estimating marine isoprene emissions?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of satellite-derived chlorophyll concentration data and meteorological reanalysis data enhances the accuracy and reliability of estimating marine isoprene emissions by providing high spatial and temporal resolution inputs, allowing for detailed calculations of biological and photochemical emissions in the marine environment. This approach addresses challenges such as data availability and emission mechanism uncertainties, offering a more comprehensive understanding of emission dynamics.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges and limitations in using empirical linear relationships between chlorophyll concentration and isoprene emissions for estimating marine BVOC emissions, especially in regions with limited data coverage?
Interpretation.Answer: The potential challenges and limitations include regional constraints of the established relationships, which may not be applicable in all situations due to localized phytoplankton populations. Additionally, limited satellite data coverage, particularly in high latitudes during winter months, poses challenges in obtaining accurate chlorophyll concentration data, leading to uncertainties in emission estimates. These limitations can result in discrepancies between observed emissions and estimations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the uncertainties in the estimated emissions of marine isoprene, particularly in high latitude regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The uncertainties in estimated emissions of marine isoprene are influenced by data availability challenges and unclear emission mechanisms. Estimations for high latitudes are particularly compromised due to limited satellite data coverage during winter months. Additionally, previous estimations did not align with current observed vertical profiles of chlorophyll and isoprene concentrations in the subsurface ocean, further contributing to the uncertainties.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a declining trend in annual total isoprene emissions across the tropical ocean from 2001 to 2020?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The dataset indicates a declining trend in annual total isoprene emissions across the tropical ocean from 2001 to 2020, potentially due to variations in phytoplankton populations and changes in marine and meteorological factors over the years. The relationships established between emissions and these factors are regionally constrained, which might lead to such observed trends.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes discrepancies between observed marine isoprene emissions and estimations obtained using previous methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Discrepancies between observed marine isoprene emissions and previous estimations arise from regionally constrained relationships between emissions and marine and meteorological factors, based on localized phytoplankton populations. These relationships may not be applicable in all situations, leading to differing results when compared to observed emissions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of diverse data sources, such as MODIS and VIIRS, impact the reliability of marine isoprene emission datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of diverse data sources like MODIS and VIIRS enhances the reliability of marine isoprene emission datasets by incorporating multiple observational parameters, such as chlorophyll concentration and radiance data, which offer a comprehensive view of the factors influencing emissions across different regions and times.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the potential impact on marine isoprene emission estimations if satellite data coverage is limited in high-latitude regions during winter months?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Limited satellite data coverage in high-latitude regions during winter months may result in less accurate estimations of marine isoprene emissions due to the inability to capture seasonal variations and specific emission mechanisms that occur under those conditions, leading to increased uncertainties.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of developing a dataset that includes both biological and photochemistry-generated marine isoprene emissions with high spatial resolution?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to provide a comprehensive, high-resolution dataset that can be used as input data for climate or atmospheric chemistry models, facilitating further studies into the impact of the air–sea system on marine secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation and its climate effect.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to incorporate both chlorophyll concentration data and meteorological reanalysis data in the creation of a marine isoprene emissions dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Incorporating both chlorophyll concentration data and meteorological reanalysis data is important to accurately estimate marine isoprene emissions by accounting for the biological and physical processes that influence emissions, thus improving the reliability of the dataset for modeling and analysis.

Goal Orientation.Question: What drives the need to update the methods used for estimating marine isoprene emissions in datasets spanning multiple decades?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The need to update methods arises from challenges related to data availability, unclear emission mechanisms, and discrepancies between previous estimations and observed emissions, as well as advancements in understanding biological, physical, and chemical processes, allowing for more accurate and comprehensive emission assessments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can one determine the dominant phytoplankton type using satellite data for the estimation of marine isoprene emissions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The dominant phytoplankton type can be determined using monthly satellite-observed normalized water-leaving radiance at 410 nm, along with seawater chlorophyll concentration data. This approach allows for the classification of phytoplankton types, which is a critical factor in estimating the isoprene production rate.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the estimation of marine isoprene emissions with high spatial and temporal resolution?
Enablement.Answer: The estimation of marine isoprene emissions with high spatial and temporal resolution is enabled by using satellite-derived ocean chlorophyll concentration data from the MODIS and the ERA5 hourly meteorological reanalysis. These methods allow for the calculation of both phytoplankton-generated biological emissions and photochemistry-generated emissions in the sea surface microlayer.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in satellite technology contribute to the accurate estimation of chlorophyll concentration and its relation to isoprene emissions?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in satellite technology contribute to accurate estimation by providing high-resolution data such as the MODIS Level 3 chlorophyll concentration and 490 nm radiative flux diffuse attenuation coefficient data, which are then averaged to fit the spatial resolution required for estimating isoprene emissions. These satellite datasets help in determining the distribution of phytoplankton types and their related emissions.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for overcoming challenges associated with estimating marine isoprene emissions in high latitude regions?
Enablement.Answer: Overcoming challenges in high latitude regions requires improved data availability and satellite coverage during winter months, as well as aligning vertical distribution estimates of chlorophyll and isoprene concentrations with current observed profiles. This may involve enhancing satellite data resolution and coverage or developing new empirical relationships that account for regional constraints and variability.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be discrepancies between observed emissions and estimated emissions obtained using traditional data collection methods in marine isoprene studies?
Expectation.Answer: Discrepancies between observed emissions and estimations might arise due to limitations in data availability, particularly in high latitudes during winter months, and unclear emission mechanisms. Additionally, previously used relationships between emissions and marine and meteorological factors, based on localized phytoplankton populations, may not be applicable in all regions, leading to estimation inaccuracies.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise from the use of satellite-derived chlorophyll concentration data when estimating marine isoprene emissions?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges could include limited satellite data coverage in high latitudes during winter and potential misalignment between estimated vertical distributions of chlorophyll and observed vertical profiles in the subsurface ocean. These limitations can introduce uncertainties in the estimated emissions.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a need to update the methods used for calculating marine isoprene emissions in datasets?
Expectation.Answer: There is a need to update methods due to advancements in understanding biological, physical, and chemical processes influencing emissions, and to incorporate the latest influencing factors and emission features. Previous methods might not fully account for the complex interactions and dynamics in the marine environment, leading to the need for more accurate and comprehensive data collection techniques.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using MODIS satellite data combined with ERA5 reanalysis for estimating marine isoprene emissions?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of using MODIS satellite data combined with ERA5 reanalysis is supported by the ability to provide high spatial resolution data necessary for estimating marine isoprene emissions. This approach leverages detailed chlorophyll concentration and meteorological data to improve the accuracy of emissions estimations, despite challenges related to data availability in high latitudes and alignment with observed vertical profiles.

Judgmental.Question: What are the perceived challenges in accurately estimating marine isoprene emissions, and how might these affect the reliability of current datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Perceived challenges include data availability, especially in high latitudes during winter months, and unclear emission mechanisms that lead to uncertainties. Discrepancies between observed emissions and estimations due to regionally constrained empirical relationships may affect the reliability of current datasets. These issues underline the importance of improving data coverage and refining emission estimation methods.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data availability affects the accuracy of marine isoprene emission estimates.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges related to data availability and unclear emission mechanisms lead to uncertainties in estimated emissions. Limited satellite data coverage, especially in high latitudes during winter months, contributes to these challenges.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how different phytoplankton types influence marine isoprene emissions.
Assertion.Answer: Phytoplankton-generated emission modules consider the classification of phytoplankton types, which are determined using satellite-observed normalized water-leaving radiance and seawater chlorophyll concentration. This classification influences the linear relationship used to estimate isoprene production rates.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose methods to address the uncertainties in the estimation of marine isoprene emissions, particularly in regions with limited satellite data coverage.
Request/Directive.Answer: To address uncertainties in marine isoprene emission estimates, particularly in regions with limited satellite data coverage, one could enhance satellite data by integrating in situ observations and remote sensing data from additional sources during periods of limited coverage, such as winter months in high-latitude regions. Developing improved empirical models that consider localized variations in phytoplankton populations and atmospheric conditions could also help reduce discrepancies and uncertainties in emission estimates.
